text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Japan Daily
Report -- Fresh data on Nanotechnology are presented in a new report.
According to news reporting originating in Yokohama, Japan, by NewsRx
journalists, research stated, "The Min system for determining the cell
division position at the center in bacteria has a unique character that uses a
protein wave (Min wave) that emerges from its components (MinD and MinE). The
Min wave emerges under the coupling of chemical reactions and molecular
diffusions of MinDE and appears when the concentrations of MinD and MinE are
similar."

Financial support for this research came from Japan Society for the Promotion
of Science.

The news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Keio University,
"However, the nanoscale mechanism to determine their concentration ranges has
remained elusive. In this study, by using artificial cells as a mimic of
cells, we showed that the dominant MinE conformations determined the allowable
concentration ranges for the emergence of the Min wave. Furthermore, the
deletion of the membrane-binding region of MinE indicated that the region was
essential for limiting the concentration ranges to be narrower."

According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "These findings
illustrate a parameter tuning mechanism underlying complex molecular systems
at the nanoscale for spatiotemporal regulation in living cells and show a
possibility that the regulation of the equilibrium among molecular
conformations can work as a switch for cell division."

For more information on this research see: Conformational equilibrium of MinE
regulates the allowable concentration ranges of a protein wave for cell
division. _Nanoscale_ , 2020;():. (Royal Society of Chemistry \-
<http://www.rsc.org/>; Nanoscale -
<http://pubs.rsc.org/en/journals/journalissues/nr>)

Our news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained by
contacting S. Kohyama, Dept. of Biosciences & Informatics, Keio University,
3-14-1 Hiyoshi, Kohoku-ku, Yokohama 223-8522, Japan. Additional authors for
this research include K. Fujiwara, N. Yoshinaga and N. Doi.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.1039/d0nr00242a>. This DOI is a link to an online
electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your
direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: Investigators at Keio University Zero in on Nanotechnology (Conformational equilibrium of MinE regulates the allowable concentration ranges of a protein wave for cell division): Nanotechnology
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Japan Daily Report -- Fresh data on Nanotechnology are presented in a new report. According to news reporting originating in Yokohama, Japan, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, “The Min system for determining the cell division position at the center in bacteria has a unique character that uses a protein wave (Min wave) that emerges from its components (MinD and MinE). The Min wave emerges under the coupling of chemical reactions and molecular diffusions of MinDE and appears when the concentrations of MinD and MinE are similar.”

Financial support for this research came from Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

The news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Keio University, “However, the nanoscale mechanism to determine their concentration ranges has remained elusive. In this study, by using artificial cells as a mimic of cells, we showed that the dominant MinE conformations determined the allowable concentration ranges for the emergence of the Min wave. Furthermore, the deletion of the membrane-binding region of MinE indicated that the region was essential for limiting the concentration ranges to be narrower.”

According to the news reporters, the research concluded: “These findings illustrate a parameter tuning mechanism underlying complex molecular systems at the nanoscale for spatiotemporal regulation in living cells and show a possibility that the regulation of the equilibrium among molecular conformations can work as a switch for cell division.”

For more information on this research see: Conformational equilibrium of MinE regulates the allowable concentration ranges of a protein wave for cell division. Nanoscale, 2020;():. (Royal Society of Chemistry - http://www.rsc.org/; Nanoscale - http://pubs.rsc.org/en/journals/journalissues/nr)

Our news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained by contacting S. Kohyama, Dept. of Biosciences & Informatics, Keio University, 3-14-1 Hiyoshi, Kohoku-ku, Yokohama 223-8522, Japan. Additional authors for this research include K. Fujiwara, N. Yoshinaga and N. Doi.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1039/d0nr00242a. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
